elements.content: In this study, a hybrid nanoassembly consisting of an upconversion nanoparticle (UCNP) core and a zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF) shell encapsulated with chiral NiSx NPs (denoted as UCNP@ZIF-NiSx) were fabricated. The UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies showed an intense circular dichroism (CD) signal at 440 and 530 nm, whereas the upconversion luminescence (UCL) signal of the UCNPs at 540 nm were quenched by NiSx NPs and the UCL signal at 660 nm was almost unchanged. By taking advantage of the chiral-optical and fluorescent signals, the dual mode nanoassemblies can be used for quantitively monitoring reactive oxygen species (ROS), with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as the proof-of-concept target in living cells. The experimental results revealed that UCNP@ZIF-NiSx has been changed into UCNP@ZIF with degradation of NiSx during the detection process. Noticeably, quantitative and selective detection of ROS was successfully carried out in vivo. This strategy highlights the potential of chiral nanoassemblies for ROS detection, which opens up a new avenue to develop the toolbox of chiral nanomaterials for biomedical and biological analysis.
elements.clean_text: In this study, a hybrid nanoassembly consisting of an upconversion nanoparticle (UCNP) core and a zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF) shell encapsulated with chiral NiSx NPs (denoted as UCNP@ZIF-NiSx) were fabricated. The UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies showed an intense circular dichroism (CD) signal at 440 and 530 nm, whereas the upconversion luminescence (UCL) signal of the UCNPs at 540 nm were quenched by NiSx NPs and the UCL signal at 660 nm was almost unchanged. By taking advantage of the chiral-optical and fluorescent signals, the dual mode nanoassemblies can be used for quantitively monitoring reactive oxygen species (ROS), with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as the proof-of-concept target in living cells. The experimental results revealed that UCNP@ZIF-NiSx has been changed into UCNP@ZIF with degradation of NiSx during the detection process. Noticeably, quantitative and selective detection of ROS was successfully carried out in vivo. This strategy highlights the potential of chiral nanoassemblies for ROS detection, which opens up a new avenue to develop the toolbox of chiral nanomaterials for biomedical and biological analysis.

elements.content: Reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as superoxide (O2–), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), hydroxyl radicals (•OH), and hypochlorite (ClO–), produced in metabolic processes, play critical roles in many physiological processes, which are crucial in health and disease. For ROS and health, the free radicals that are produced by phagocytes can kill the invading pathogenic microbes. Moreover, ROS play an important role in the function of cellular signaling systems. For ROS and disease, the ROS-related disease can be caused by either a shortage of ROS or a surplus of ROS. The lack of ROS can lead to the abnormal immune function, which can further result in chronic granulomatous disease. The overproduction of ROS can cause cell death, organ injury, and a wide range of diseases (such as cancers, rheumatoid arthritis, cardiovascular diseases, and neurological diseases), some of which can lead to death. Therefore, rapid and accurate determination of ROS levels is of great importance. During the past decades, a series of probes (especially fluorescent probes and electrochemical sensors) have been developed for the detection of ROS. However, their application can sometimes be limited by their poor biocompatibility, low sensitivity, and photobleaching effects. Furthermore, the background autofluorescence of complex biological matrices can also hinder the quantification of ROS in living organisms.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as superoxide (O2-), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), hydroxyl radicals (⋅OH), and hypochlorite (ClO-), produced in metabolic processes, play critical roles in many physiological processes, which are crucial in health and disease. For ROS and health, the free radicals that are produced by phagocytes can kill the invading pathogenic microbes. Moreover, ROS play an important role in the function of cellular signaling systems. For ROS and disease, the ROS-related disease can be caused by either a shortage of ROS or a surplus of ROS. The lack of ROS can lead to the abnormal immune function, which can further result in chronic granulomatous disease. The overproduction of ROS can cause cell death, organ injury, and a wide range of diseases (such as cancers, rheumatoid arthritis, cardiovascular diseases, and neurological diseases), some of which can lead to death. Therefore, rapid and accurate determination of ROS levels is of great importance. During the past decades, a series of probes (especially fluorescent probes and electrochemical sensors) have been developed for the detection of ROS. However, their application can sometimes be limited by their poor biocompatibility, low sensitivity, and photobleaching effects. Furthermore, the background autofluorescence of complex biological matrices can also hinder the quantification of ROS in living organisms.

elements.content: Recently, chiral nanomaterials including individual chiral nanoparticles (NPs) and chiral nanoassemblies have attracted tremendous interest due to their potential applications in chiral sensing, optoelectronics, and asymmetric catalysis. Individual chiral NPs, such as chiral WO3‑x NPs, chiral carbon dots, chiral MoO3‑x NPs, chiral CdTe NPs, chiral Co3O4 NPs, chiral plasmonic gold NPs, and chiral Cu2‑x S NPs, have been prepared and used for peptide catalysis and DNA profiling. In addition, chiral NP assemblies with strong chiroptical activity in the visible spectrum, that avoids the interference from background circular dichroism (CD) signals from the organism, have been applied to biological analysis.
elements.clean_text: Recently, chiral nanomaterials including individual chiral nanoparticles (NPs) and chiral nanoassemblies have attracted tremendous interest due to their potential applications in chiral sensing, optoelectronics, and asymmetric catalysis. Individual chiral NPs, such as chiral WO3-x  NPs, chiral carbon dots, chiral MoO3-x  NPs, chiral CdTe NPs, chiral Co3O4 NPs, chiral plasmonic gold NPs, and chiral Cu2-x S NPs, have been prepared and used for peptide catalysis and DNA profiling. In addition, chiral NP assemblies with strong chiroptical activity in the visible spectrum, that avoids the interference from background circular dichroism (CD) signals from the organism, have been applied to biological analysis.

elements.content: The lanthanide-doped upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs) that can convert near-infrared radiation into visible light have been widely utilized in constructing probes. Zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) is a subclass of metal–organic framework (MOF) with excellent biocompatibility and tunable pore openings. Notably, integrating UCNPs with chiral NPs is a good strategy for the creation of composite nanoassembliess, which can possibly utilize both CD and upconversion luminescent (UCL) signals. The MOF could be used as a good bridge to combine both functional nanomaterials into one system. Li et al. and Yuan et al. fabricated the hybrid nanocomposites of UCNP and MOF and applied to photodynamic therapy.
elements.clean_text: The lanthanide-doped upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs) that can convert near-infrared radiation into visible light have been widely utilized in constructing probes. Zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) is a subclass of metal-organic framework (MOF) with excellent biocompatibility and tunable pore openings. Notably, integrating UCNPs with chiral NPs is a good strategy for the creation of composite nanoassembliess, which can possibly utilize both CD and upconversion luminescent (UCL) signals. The MOF could be used as a good bridge to combine both functional nanomaterials into one system. Li et al. and Yuan et al. fabricated the hybrid nanocomposites of UCNP and MOF and applied to photodynamic therapy.

elements.content: In this study, the hybrid chiral core–shell nanostructure including a UCNP (NaYF4:Yb3+/Er3+) core and a chiral NiSx NPs-decorated MOF shell was constructed (denoted “UCNP@ZIF-NiSx”). Chiral NiSx NPs were synthesized using a chiral penicillamine template, showing a CD signal which sensitively and selectively responded to ROS. With the CD and UCL signals of the hybrid nanoplatform, we achieved ultrasensitive and selective detection of ROS in live cells and in vivo.
elements.clean_text: In this study, the hybrid chiral core-shell nanostructure including a UCNP (NaYF4:Yb3+/Er3+) core and a chiral NiSx NPs-decorated MOF shell was constructed (denoted "UCNP@ZIF-NiSx"). Chiral NiSx NPs were synthesized using a chiral penicillamine template, showing a CD signal which sensitively and selectively responded to ROS. With the CD and UCL signals of the hybrid nanoplatform, we achieved ultrasensitive and selective detection of ROS in live cells and in vivo.

elements.content: The process for preparing the nanoassemblies is shown in . This strategy was based on the interaction between UCNPs and MOF precursors at room temperature. First, the UNCPs were stabilized by oleic acid (UCNPs-OA) with a hexagonal plate-like appearance, and were prepared and used as the initial core (Figures S1 and S2). Because of the hydrophobic surface of UCNPs-OA, hydrochloric acid was used to remove the OA ligands. Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) was then coated onto the bare UCNP (Figure S3), forming the water-soluble UCNPs-PVP (Figure S4). Then, a ZIF-8 layer was coated onto the UCNP nanodisks to form the hydrophilic UCNP@ZIF core–shell nanostructure. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images clearly showed the obvious core–shell geometry, indicating successful synthesis of UCNP@ZIF structures (A and S5). Finally, by using nickel ions (II) as a nickel source and chiral L-/D-Pen ligands as a sulfide source, the chiral NiSx-L/D NPs could be nucleated and grown into the ZIF shell to form the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L/D composite (B and S6). High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) analysis exhibited lattice spacing of 0.52 nm, which was assigned to NaYF4 (100), and the thickness of ZIF-8 shell was about 7 nm (C). Elemental mapping results clearly showed all expected elements including the detection of Y, Yb, Zn, Ni, and S in the nanoassemblies (D). Porosity of the nanocomposite was characterized by the nitrogen sorption–desorption isotherms. As shown in Figure S7, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx was 416.1 m2/g, which was smaller than that of the UCNP@ZIF (966.8 m2/g). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique was employed to characterize the structural evolution of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L (A). The XRD peaks of UCNP were matched with the standard pattern of pure β-phase NaYF4 crystals (JCPDS no. 16-0334). After coating the ZIF-8 shell, in addition to the XRD peaks from the UCNP, the UCNP@ZIF also displayed peaks that can be indexed to the pattern of ZIF-8. Furthermore, UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L displayed similar peaks to UCNP@ZIF, indicating that the NiSx loading did not alter the parent crystalline structure.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization of the Nanoassemblies

The process for preparing the nanoassemblies is shown in . This strategy was based on the interaction between UCNPs and MOF precursors at room temperature. First, the UNCPs were stabilized by oleic acid (UCNPs-OA) with a hexagonal plate-like appearance, and were prepared and used as the initial core (Figures S1 and S2). Because of the hydrophobic surface of UCNPs-OA, hydrochloric acid was used to remove the OA ligands. Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) was then coated onto the bare UCNP (Figure S3), forming the water-soluble UCNPs-PVP (Figure S4). Then, a ZIF-8 layer was coated onto the UCNP nanodisks to form the hydrophilic UCNP@ZIF core-shell nanostructure. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images clearly showed the obvious core-shell geometry, indicating successful synthesis of UCNP@ZIF structures (A and S5). Finally, by using nickel ions (II) as a nickel source and chiral L-/D-Pen ligands as a sulfide source, the chiral NiSx-L/D NPs could be nucleated and grown into the ZIF shell to form the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L/D composite (B and S6). High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) analysis exhibited lattice spacing of 0.52 nm, which was assigned to NaYF4 (100), and the thickness of ZIF-8 shell was about 7 nm (C). Elemental mapping results clearly showed all expected elements including the detection of Y, Yb, Zn, Ni, and S in the nanoassemblies (D). Porosity of the nanocomposite was characterized by the nitrogen sorption-desorption isotherms. As shown in Figure S7, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx was 416.1 m2/g, which was smaller than that of the UCNP@ZIF (966.8 m2/g). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique was employed to characterize the structural evolution of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L (A). The XRD peaks of UCNP were matched with the standard pattern of pure β-phase NaYF4 crystals (JCPDS no. 16-0334). After coating the ZIF-8 shell, in addition to the XRD peaks from the UCNP, the UCNP@ZIF also displayed peaks that can be indexed to the pattern of ZIF-8. Furthermore, UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L displayed similar peaks to UCNP@ZIF, indicating that the NiSx loading did not alter the parent crystalline structure.

elements.content: ROS detection using UCNP@MOF-NiSx nanoassemblies.
elements.clean_text: 1  ROS detection using UCNP@MOF-NiSx nanoassemblies.

(C) High-resolution TEM image of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx. (D) Dark-field TEM image of one single UCNP@ZIF-NiSx and the corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy element mapping of Y, Yb, Zn, Ni, and S elements.
elements.clean_text: 2  TEM image of the (A) UCNP@ZIF nanostructure and (B) UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies; inset is the high-resolution TEM image of NiSx in the nanoassemblies. (C) High-resolution TEM image of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx. (D) Dark-field TEM image of one single UCNP@ZIF-NiSx and the corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy element mapping of Y, Yb, Zn, Ni, and S elements.

elements.content: (A) XRD spectra of UCNP-PVP, ZIF-8, and UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies. (B) XPS spectrum of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies (Ni 2p scan).
elements.clean_text: 3  (A) XRD spectra of UCNP-PVP, ZIF-8, and UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies. (B) XPS spectrum of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies (Ni 2p scan).

elements.content: The XPS spectra of Ni and S were also measured to study the chemical states of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L (B and S8). The difference between the Ni 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 peaks was set at 17.5 eV. The deconvoluted Ni 2p consisted of two spin–orbit doublets and two satellites that were assigned to Ni2+ (852.7 and 870.2 eV), and Ni3+ (855.2 and 872.7 eV).
elements.clean_text: The XPS spectra of Ni and S were also measured to study the chemical states of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L (B and S8). The difference between the Ni 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 peaks was set at 17.5 eV. The deconvoluted Ni 2p consisted of two spin-orbit doublets and two satellites that were assigned to Ni2+ (852.7 and 870.2 eV), and Ni3+ (855.2 and 872.7 eV).

elements.content: The CD spectrum of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L is shown in Figure S9, indicating two intense CD signals at 440 and 530 nm, whereas the UCNP-PVP and UCNP@ZIF displayed a silent CD response. These results indicated that the chirality of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L was from the chiral NiSx-L NPs. To confirm this assumption, dispersed chiral NiSx-L NPs were prepared. The TEM image in Figure S10 shows that the diameter of the chiral NiSx-L NPs was about 3.5 nm. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was conducted to analyze the changes in mercapto groups (−SH). As shown in Figure S11, FTIR of the chiral L-pen showed a peak at 2586 cm–1, which was assigned to the stretching and vibration of the S–H bond. After formation of the chiral NiSx-L NPs, the peak completely disappeared, indicating cleavage of the S–H bond by the strong covalent binding of thiol groups to Ni atoms on the surface of the NiSx-L NPs. The CD spectrum of the chiral NiSx-L NPs (Figure S12) showed a similar CD response to UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L, further confirming the existence of chiral NiSx-L NPs in the nanoassemblies. Notably, the NiSx-L and NiSx-D NPs which were induced by the chiral L-pen and D-pen displayed mirror image CD lines (Figure S12). Absorption spectra were carried out to characterize the optical activity of the prepared nanomaterials. As displayed in Figure S13, chiral NiSx NPs showed absorption peaks at 415 and 535 nm, and the absorption of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L was in accordance with chiral NiSx-L, demonstrating that NiSx-L NPs were assembled into UCNP@ZIF successfully. Concurrently, the UCL of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L at 540 nm was dramatically quenched by NiSx-L NPs (Figure S14).
elements.clean_text: The CD spectrum of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L is shown in Figure S9, indicating two intense CD signals at 440 and 530 nm, whereas the UCNP-PVP and UCNP@ZIF displayed a silent CD response. These results indicated that the chirality of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L was from the chiral NiSx-L NPs. To confirm this assumption, dispersed chiral NiSx-L NPs were prepared. The TEM image in Figure S10 shows that the diameter of the chiral NiSx-L NPs was about 3.5 nm. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was conducted to analyze the changes in mercapto groups (-SH). As shown in Figure S11, FTIR of the chiral L-pen showed a peak at 2586 cm-1, which was assigned to the stretching and vibration of the S-H bond. After formation of the chiral NiSx-L NPs, the peak completely disappeared, indicating cleavage of the S-H bond by the strong covalent binding of thiol groups to Ni atoms on the surface of the NiSx-L NPs. The CD spectrum of the chiral NiSx-L NPs (Figure S12) showed a similar CD response to UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L, further confirming the existence of chiral NiSx-L NPs in the nanoassemblies. Notably, the NiSx-L and NiSx-D NPs which were induced by the chiral L-pen and D-pen displayed mirror image CD lines (Figure S12). Absorption spectra were carried out to characterize the optical activity of the prepared nanomaterials. As displayed in Figure S13, chiral NiSx NPs showed absorption peaks at 415 and 535 nm, and the absorption of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L was in accordance with chiral NiSx-L, demonstrating that NiSx-L NPs were assembled into UCNP@ZIF successfully. Concurrently, the UCL of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L at 540 nm was dramatically quenched by NiSx-L NPs (Figure S14).

elements.content: As a major ROS, H2O2 is a messenger involved in cell signaling, and is also involved in the pathogenesis of various diseases (including cancers, diabetes, and neurodegenerative diseases). We have selected H2O2 as the model of ROS in our following experiments. The CD intensity of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L was decreased after the addition of H2O2 (Figure S15). The mechanism of H2O2-mediated CD decrease of the nanoassemblies could be due to the degradation of the NiSx NPs by H2O2. As shown in Figures S16 and S17, the absorption intensity and CD response of NiSx-L NPs were decreased after the addition of H2O2, along with the loss of color (Figure S18). The change of Ni content in the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx was confirmed by HAADF-STEM-EDS elemental mapping and line scan (Figure S19). The elemental Ni content of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx specifically decreased after reaction with H2O2, and this was further confirmed by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The ratio of Zn:Ni in the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx was 6.9:3.1, which changed to 9.85:0.15 after addition of H2O2 (Table S1), suggesting the consumption of Ni. These results indicated that degradation of NiSx during the reaction with H2O2 changed UCNP@ZIF-NiSx into UCNP@ZIF.
elements.clean_text:
Responsiveness of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx to ROS

As a major ROS, H2O2 is a messenger involved in cell signaling, and is also involved in the pathogenesis of various diseases (including cancers, diabetes, and neurodegenerative diseases). We have selected H2O2 as the model of ROS in our following experiments. The CD intensity of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L was decreased after the addition of H2O2 (Figure S15). The mechanism of H2O2-mediated CD decrease of the nanoassemblies could be due to the degradation of the NiSx NPs by H2O2. As shown in Figures S16 and S17, the absorption intensity and CD response of NiSx-L NPs were decreased after the addition of H2O2, along with the loss of color (Figure S18). The change of Ni content in the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx was confirmed by HAADF-STEM-EDS elemental mapping and line scan (Figure S19). The elemental Ni content of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx specifically decreased after reaction with H2O2, and this was further confirmed by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The ratio of Zn:Ni in the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx was 6.9:3.1, which changed to 9.85:0.15 after addition of H2O2 (Table S1), suggesting the consumption of Ni. These results indicated that degradation of NiSx during the reaction with H2O2 changed UCNP@ZIF-NiSx into UCNP@ZIF.

elements.content: More importantly, the change of CD signal exhibited a perfect linear relationship with the H2O2 concentration ranging from 0.05 to 20 μM, and the LOD was 0.032 μM. (A and S20). We next tested the feasibility of this probe for its ability to detect H2O2 using a luminescent signal. As shown in Figure S21, the absorption of the probe spectrally overlaps with the green emission (540 nm) of the UCNPs. Reaction of H2O2 with the probe caused a decrease in probe absorption at 660 nm, which will then increase the I 660/I 540 ratio of the probe (B). A plot of I 660/I 540 ratio versus H2O2 concentration in the range of 0.05 to 20 μM shows a linear response, and LOD was calculated to be 0.037 μM (Figure S22). Next, the selectivity of this probe was tested. In the presence of ROS, the CD signal disappeared, and the luminescent signal was restored, whereas no obvious changes in the CD or luminescent signals were observed with possible interfering components. This suggested that this detection probe had a perfect specificity (C,D and S23, S24). Therefore, the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx probe had adequate sensitivity and excellent selectivity for the detection of ROS under physiological conditions.
elements.clean_text: More importantly, the change of CD signal exhibited a perfect linear relationship with the H2O2 concentration ranging from 0.05 to 20 μM, and the LOD was 0.032 μM. (A and S20). We next tested the feasibility of this probe for its ability to detect H2O2 using a luminescent signal. As shown in Figure S21, the absorption of the probe spectrally overlaps with the green emission (540 nm) of the UCNPs. Reaction of H2O2 with the probe caused a decrease in probe absorption at 660 nm, which will then increase the I 660/I 540 ratio of the probe (B). A plot of I 660/I 540 ratio versus H2O2 concentration in the range of 0.05 to 20 μM shows a linear response, and LOD was calculated to be 0.037 μM (Figure S22). Next, the selectivity of this probe was tested. In the presence of ROS, the CD signal disappeared, and the luminescent signal was restored, whereas no obvious changes in the CD or luminescent signals were observed with possible interfering components. This suggested that this detection probe had a perfect specificity (C,D and S23, S24). Therefore, the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx probe had adequate sensitivity and excellent selectivity for the detection of ROS under physiological conditions.

elements.content: (A) CD and (B) UCL spectra of the nanoassemblies responded to different concentrations of H2O2 in vitro. (C) CD and (D) UCL intensity of the nanoassemblies responded to other ROS (100 μM) and different coexistents (1 mM) in vitro. Error bars are obtained from three parallel samples. λex = 980 nm.
elements.clean_text: 4  (A) CD and (B) UCL spectra of the nanoassemblies responded to different concentrations of H2O2 in vitro. (C) CD and (D) UCL intensity of the nanoassemblies responded to other ROS (100 μM) and different coexistents (1 mM) in vitro. Error bars are obtained from three parallel samples. λex = 980 nm.

elements.content: The cytotoxicity and stability of the probe was first examined. As shown in Figure S25, the nanoassemblies displayed negligible cytotoxicity in living cells. In addition, the nanoassemblies also displayed good stability in cell culture media (Figures S26 and S27). These results lay a solid foundation for intracellular detection of ROS in living cells.
elements.clean_text:
Sensing H2O2 in Living Cells

The cytotoxicity and stability of the probe was first examined. As shown in Figure S25, the nanoassemblies displayed negligible cytotoxicity in living cells. In addition, the nanoassemblies also displayed good stability in cell culture media (Figures S26 and S27). These results lay a solid foundation for intracellular detection of ROS in living cells.

elements.content: To determine the various levels of H2O2 in living cells, normal primary uterine fibroblast cells (PCS-460-010) were treated with N-acetylcysteine (NAC) to eliminate intracellular ROS. They were then incubated with varying concentrations of H2O2 to increase intracellular H2O2 levels. After treatment, intracellular H2O2 was quantified with a hydrogen peroxide assay kit. For UCL signal detection, the PCS-460-010 cells were incubated with the nanoassemblies and then confocal images were taken under an optical microscope equipped with a 980 nm laser. As shown in A, the green UCL signal as expected increased, whereas the red UCL signal remained unchanged, with an increase in intracellular H2O2 concentration. The UCL signal allowed a linear relationship ranging from 0.18 to 10.2 μΜ, and the LOD was 0.13 μΜ, which is much lower than the H2O2 level (∼35 μM) in human blood plasma.
elements.clean_text: To determine the various levels of H2O2 in living cells, normal primary uterine fibroblast cells (PCS-460-010) were treated with N-acetylcysteine (NAC) to eliminate intracellular ROS. They were then incubated with varying concentrations of H2O2 to increase intracellular H2O2 levels. After treatment, intracellular H2O2 was quantified with a hydrogen peroxide assay kit. For UCL signal detection, the PCS-460-010 cells were incubated with the nanoassemblies and then confocal images were taken under an optical microscope equipped with a 980 nm laser. As shown in A, the green UCL signal as expected increased, whereas the red UCL signal remained unchanged, with an increase in intracellular H2O2 concentration. The UCL signal allowed a linear relationship ranging from 0.18 to 10.2 μΜ, and the LOD was 0.13 μΜ, which is much lower than the H2O2 level (~35 μM) in human blood plasma.

elements.content: Dual-mode detection of H2O2 by CD and UCL signal based on the novel UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies in living cells: (A) Confocal images of the probe-pretreated PCS-460-010 cells reacting with various concentrations of H2O2: (a1) 0.18 μM, (a2) 1.47 μM, (a3) 4.89 μM, (a4) 7.7 μM, and (a5) 10.2 μM. Excitation was at 980 nm and power was 500 mW. Scale bars: 25 μm. (B) Standard curves for H2O2 corresponding to fluorescence ratio (I 660/I 540). (C,D) CD spectra of preincubated HeLa cells with the probe further treated with different concentrations of H2O2.
elements.clean_text: 5  Dual-mode detection of H2O2 by CD and UCL signal based on the novel UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies in living cells: (A) Confocal images of the probe-pretreated PCS-460-010 cells reacting with various concentrations of H2O2: (a1) 0.18 μM, (a2) 1.47 μM, (a3) 4.89 μM, (a4) 7.7 μM, and (a5) 10.2 μM. Excitation was at 980 nm and power was 500 mW. Scale bars: 25 μm. (B) Standard curves for H2O2 corresponding to fluorescence ratio (I 660/I 540). (C,D) CD spectra of preincubated HeLa cells with the probe further treated with different concentrations of H2O2.

elements.content: The intracellular CD signal was obtained after the PCS-460-010 cells were incubated with the probe for 4 h (C). As can be seen in the CD spectra, the CD intensity decreased as the concentration of ROS increased in the cells, exhibiting a good linear relationship with the concentration of H2O2 (D). The detection range of the CD signal was 0.18–10.2 μM, and the LOD was calculated to be 0.09 μM.
elements.clean_text: The intracellular CD signal was obtained after the PCS-460-010 cells were incubated with the probe for 4 h (C). As can be seen in the CD spectra, the CD intensity decreased as the concentration of ROS increased in the cells, exhibiting a good linear relationship with the concentration of H2O2 (D). The detection range of the CD signal was 0.18-10.2 μM, and the LOD was calculated to be 0.09 μM.

elements.content: To confirm general applicability of this probe, the detection of intracellular ROS levels was also carried out in human epithelial cancer cells (HeLa cells) and human melanoma SK-MEL-2 cells (A and S28). For HeLa cells, the intracellular H2O2 level was calculated to be 2.29 ± 0.21 μM and 2.43 ± 0.17 μM from the CD mode and UCL mode, respectively. For SK-MEL-2 cells, the CD and UCL detection results were 1.33 ± 0.23 μM and 1.37 ± 0.18 μM, respectively. All the results were consistent and comparable to those found using the H2O2 Kit, demonstrating that the nanoassemblies displayed excellent versatility among various cell lines. For the HeLa cells treated with NAC, the intensity of the CD response was much higher than that of the original untreated cells, whereas after treatment with lipopolysaccharide (LPS, an upregulator of ROS), the CD signal intensity was much weaker than that of untreated cells (Figure S29), suggesting that this probe could be applied to detect changes of intracellular H2O2 levels. It was found that the sensitivity of UCL detection was lower than that of CD detection which could be attributed to the high sensitivity and responsiveness of chiral NiSx NPs to the H2O2 analytes.
elements.clean_text: To confirm general applicability of this probe, the detection of intracellular ROS levels was also carried out in human epithelial cancer cells (HeLa cells) and human melanoma SK-MEL-2 cells (A and S28). For HeLa cells, the intracellular H2O2 level was calculated to be 2.29 ± 0.21 μM and 2.43 ± 0.17 μM from the CD mode and UCL mode, respectively. For SK-MEL-2 cells, the CD and UCL detection results were 1.33 ± 0.23 μM and 1.37 ± 0.18 μM, respectively. All the results were consistent and comparable to those found using the H2O2 Kit, demonstrating that the nanoassemblies displayed excellent versatility among various cell lines. For the HeLa cells treated with NAC, the intensity of the CD response was much higher than that of the original untreated cells, whereas after treatment with lipopolysaccharide (LPS, an upregulator of ROS), the CD signal intensity was much weaker than that of untreated cells (Figure S29), suggesting that this probe could be applied to detect changes of intracellular H2O2 levels. It was found that the sensitivity of UCL detection was lower than that of CD detection which could be attributed to the high sensitivity and responsiveness of chiral NiSx NPs to the H2O2 analytes.

elements.content: Application of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies in living cells and in vivo. (A) Confocal images of PCS-460-010 cells, HeLa, and SK-MEL-2 cells after treatment with UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies. Scale bars: 25 μm. (B) UCL imaging of ROS in a HeLa-tumor bearing-mouse. Equimolar amounts of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies were injected subcutaneously into tumors (L, probe-treated tumor; R, tumor pretreated with N-acetylcysteine followed by injection of probe), and fluorescent images were taken at various time points after injection: (b1) control, (b2) 0 min, (b3) 10 min, (b4) 20 min, (b5) 30 min, and (b6) 40 min. Excitation at 980 nm and power was 500 mW.
elements.clean_text: 6  Application of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies in living cells and in vivo. (A) Confocal images of PCS-460-010 cells, HeLa, and SK-MEL-2 cells after treatment with UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies. Scale bars: 25 μm. (B) UCL imaging of ROS in a HeLa-tumor bearing-mouse. Equimolar amounts of the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies were injected subcutaneously into tumors (L, probe-treated tumor; R, tumor pretreated with N-acetylcysteine followed by injection of probe), and fluorescent images were taken at various time points after injection: (b1) control, (b2) 0 min, (b3) 10 min, (b4) 20 min, (b5) 30 min, and (b6) 40 min. Excitation at 980 nm and power was 500 mW.

elements.content: To test the biosafety of this nanoprobe in vivo, hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained images of five major organs (heart, liver, kidney, spleen, and lung) and serum biochemistry tests were carried out. As shown in Figures S30 and S31, the results suggested that almost no damage was observed in the nanoprobe-treated mice.
elements.clean_text:
UCNP@ZIF Nanoprobe for ROS Detection in vivo 

To test the biosafety of this nanoprobe in vivo, hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained images of five major organs (heart, liver, kidney, spleen, and lung) and serum biochemistry tests were carried out. As shown in Figures S30 and S31, the results suggested that almost no damage was observed in the nanoprobe-treated mice.

elements.content: By using a tumor-bearing mouse model, the applicability of this nanoprobe for ROS detection in vivo was evaluated, and the nanoprobes were injected into the HeLa-tumors of the same mouse (B and S32). Significantly, within 10 min post-injection of the probe, an intense UCL signal was observed, indicating a fast response of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx to ROS in vivo. This specific signal in the tumors increased with time and reached a plateau within 40 min after probe injection. However, when the tumor site was treated with NAC (ROS scavenger), minimal UCL signal was observed after the probe injection, revealing low levels of ROS. These results indicated that UCNP@ZIF-NiSx can be applied for rapid semiquantitative analysis and tracking of endogenous ROS in vivo.
elements.clean_text: By using a tumor-bearing mouse model, the applicability of this nanoprobe for ROS detection in vivo was evaluated, and the nanoprobes were injected into the HeLa-tumors of the same mouse (B and S32). Significantly, within 10 min post-injection of the probe, an intense UCL signal was observed, indicating a fast response of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx to ROS in vivo. This specific signal in the tumors increased with time and reached a plateau within 40 min after probe injection. However, when the tumor site was treated with NAC (ROS scavenger), minimal UCL signal was observed after the probe injection, revealing low levels of ROS. These results indicated that UCNP@ZIF-NiSx can be applied for rapid semiquantitative analysis and tracking of endogenous ROS in vivo.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have developed an ultrasensitive and selective method for H2O2 detection, which takes advantage of the transformation of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx into UCNP@ZIF. The findings exhibit that MOFs are the prior candidates as building blocks for chiral nanoassemblies. We envisage that this dual-response nanoassembled platform can be extended to diagnose biomarker targets, and this strategy will facilitate the progress of chiral nanoassemblies for bioapplications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, we have developed an ultrasensitive and selective method for H2O2 detection, which takes advantage of the transformation of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx into UCNP@ZIF. The findings exhibit that MOFs are the prior candidates as building blocks for chiral nanoassemblies. We envisage that this dual-response nanoassembled platform can be extended to diagnose biomarker targets, and this strategy will facilitate the progress of chiral nanoassemblies for bioapplications.

cln_elements.content:
The CD spectrum of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L is shown in Figure S9, indicating two intense CD signals at 440 and 530 nm, whereas the UCNP-PVP and UCNP@ZIF displayed a silent CD response. These results indicated that the chirality of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L was from the chiral NiSx-L NPs. To confirm this assumption, dispersed chiral NiSx-L NPs were prepared. The TEM image in Figure S10 shows that the diameter of the chiral NiSx-L NPs was about 3.5 nm. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was conducted to analyze the changes in mercapto groups (−SH). As shown in Figure S11, FTIR of the chiral L-pen showed a peak at 2586 cm–1, which was assigned to the stretching and vibration of the S–H bond. After formation of the chiral NiSx-L NPs, the peak completely disappeared, indicating cleavage of the S–H bond by the strong covalent binding of thiol groups to Ni atoms on the surface of the NiSx-L NPs. The CD spectrum of the chiral NiSx-L NPs (Figure S12) showed a similar CD response to UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L, further confirming the existence of chiral NiSx-L NPs in the nanoassemblies. Notably, the NiSx-L and NiSx-D NPs which were induced by the chiral L-pen and D-pen displayed mirror image CD lines (Figure S12). Absorption spectra were carried out to characterize the optical activity of the prepared nanomaterials. As displayed in Figure S13, chiral NiSx NPs showed absorption peaks at 415 and 535 nm, and the absorption of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L was in accordance with chiral NiSx-L, demonstrating that NiSx-L NPs were assembled into UCNP@ZIF successfully. Concurrently, the UCL of UCNP@ZIF-NiSx-L at 540 nm was dramatically quenched by NiSx-L NPs (Figure S14).

More importantly, the change of CD signal exhibited a perfect linear relationship with the H2O2 concentration ranging from 0.05 to 20 μM, and the LOD was 0.032 μM. (A and S20). We next tested the feasibility of this probe for its ability to detect H2O2 using a luminescent signal. As shown in Figure S21, the absorption of the probe spectrally overlaps with the green emission (540 nm) of the UCNPs. Reaction of H2O2 with the probe caused a decrease in probe absorption at 660 nm, which will then increase the I 660/I 540 ratio of the probe (B). A plot of I 660/I 540 ratio versus H2O2 concentration in the range of 0.05 to 20 μM shows a linear response, and LOD was calculated to be 0.037 μM (Figure S22). Next, the selectivity of this probe was tested. In the presence of ROS, the CD signal disappeared, and the luminescent signal was restored, whereas no obvious changes in the CD or luminescent signals were observed with possible interfering components. This suggested that this detection probe had a perfect specificity (C,D and S23, S24). Therefore, the UCNP@ZIF-NiSx probe had adequate sensitivity and excellent selectivity for the detection of ROS under physiological conditions.

To determine the various levels of H2O2 in living cells, normal primary uterine fibroblast cells (PCS-460-010) were treated with N-acetylcysteine (NAC) to eliminate intracellular ROS. They were then incubated with varying concentrations of H2O2 to increase intracellular H2O2 levels. After treatment, intracellular H2O2 was quantified with a hydrogen peroxide assay kit. For UCL signal detection, the PCS-460-010 cells were incubated with the nanoassemblies and then confocal images were taken under an optical microscope equipped with a 980 nm laser. As shown in A, the green UCL signal as expected increased, whereas the red UCL signal remained unchanged, with an increase in intracellular H2O2 concentration. The UCL signal allowed a linear relationship ranging from 0.18 to 10.2 μΜ, and the LOD was 0.13 μΜ, which is much lower than the H2O2 level (∼35 μM) in human blood plasma.

The intracellular CD signal was obtained after the PCS-460-010 cells were incubated with the probe for 4 h (C). As can be seen in the CD spectra, the CD intensity decreased as the concentration of ROS increased in the cells, exhibiting a good linear relationship with the concentration of H2O2 (D). The detection range of the CD signal was 0.18–10.2 μM, and the LOD was calculated to be 0.09 μM.

To confirm general applicability of this probe, the detection of intracellular ROS levels was also carried out in human epithelial cancer cells (HeLa cells) and human melanoma SK-MEL-2 cells (A and S28). For HeLa cells, the intracellular H2O2 level was calculated to be 2.29 ± 0.21 μM and 2.43 ± 0.17 μM from the CD mode and UCL mode, respectively. For SK-MEL-2 cells, the CD and UCL detection results were 1.33 ± 0.23 μM and 1.37 ± 0.18 μM, respectively. All the results were consistent and comparable to those found using the H2O2 Kit, demonstrating that the nanoassemblies displayed excellent versatility among various cell lines. For the HeLa cells treated with NAC, the intensity of the CD response was much higher than that of the original untreated cells, whereas after treatment with lipopolysaccharide (LPS, an upregulator of ROS), the CD signal intensity was much weaker than that of untreated cells (Figure S29), suggesting that this probe could be applied to detect changes of intracellular H2O2 levels. It was found that the sensitivity of UCL detection was lower than that of CD detection which could be attributed to the high sensitivity and responsiveness of chiral NiSx NPs to the H2O2 analytes.

(C) CD and (D) UCL intensity of the nanoassemblies responded to other ROS (100 μM) and different coexistents (1 mM) in vitro. Error bars are obtained from three parallel samples. λex = 980 nm.

cln_elements.content: Dual-mode detection of H2O2 by CD and UCL signal based on the novel UCNP@ZIF-NiSx nanoassemblies in living cells: (A) Confocal images of the probe-pretreated PCS-460-010 cells reacting with various concentrations of H2O2: (a1) 0.18 μM, (a2) 1.47 μM, (a3) 4.89 μM, (a4) 7.7 μM, and (a5) 10.2 μM. Excitation was at 980 nm and power was 500 mW. Scale bars: 25 μm. (B) Standard curves for H2O2 corresponding to fluorescence ratio (I 660/I 540). (C,D) CD spectra of preincubated HeLa cells with the probe further treated with different concentrations of H2O2.
